footnotes: 'You may be made partakers of the divine nature' (theias koinōnoi physeōs)—the scriptural basis for theosis (divinization).
We are not merely forgiven but transformed, sharing in God's own nature through grace. As St. Athanasius said: 'God became man that man might become god.'
This participation is real but analogical—we share in divinity by grace, not by nature. We become 'gods' by gift, not by essence.
'The prophetical word more confirmed'—the apostles' eyewitness testimony confirms and illuminates OT prophecy.
Peter ranks Scripture highly: 'a light that shineth in a dark place, until the day dawn.'
'No prophecy of scripture is made by private interpretation'—Scripture is not for individualistic interpretation but must be read within the Church's tradition.
This verse cautions against the idea that each reader can authoritatively interpret Scripture apart from the community of faith.
'Holy men of God spoke, inspired by the Holy Ghost'—divine inspiration: God is the primary author of Scripture through human instruments.
The prophets were 'moved' (pheromenoi)—carried along by the Spirit, not merely using their natural faculties.
'Some things hard to understand, which the unlearned and unstable wrest... to their own destruction.'
Peter acknowledges difficulty in Paul's letters and warns against distorting them. Authoritative interpretation is necessary.
The Church's Magisterium exists precisely to prevent such destructive misreadings of Scripture.
